results.title: The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit glass slides (Butterflies)
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by William Kerr on behalf of Edwin Schefferle.
results.brief_description: There are six parts to the butterflies slides, each slide has 4 images. These small slides have red sealing tape around the edges. These slides form part of The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit with removable chimney and internal wooden block. The lantern is housed in original box with metal handle, and internal red and blue graphic for: The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit. 20 glass slides in custom box, length of textile to keep box shut, 2 small empty boxes which act to store slides in a snug manner.

results.title: 70mm cement splicer
results.material_description: Painted cast iron, stainless steel, rubber
results.brief_description: A film splicer is an essential tool for film editing, enabling the physical joining of film strips. This splicer is designed for cement joins on 70mm film, the largest standard motion picture format. Splicing with cement requires the removal of photographic emulsion from the film end, application of film cement (a solvent-based adhesive) and precise alignment when fusing the two film segments. Cement splices create a strong join along the frame edge and is usually not visible when film is projected.

results.title: Mechanical magic lantern slides
results.brief_description: Mechanical magic lantern slides created basic moving pictures. ‘Slipping slides’ used two glass slides featuring complementary images – one stationary and one that ‘slipped’ over the other to give the illusion of movement, while levers and pulley systems were also incorporated to create dynamic effects.

constellations_primary.name: Kaleidoscopic colour: Chromotrope
constellations_primary.description: A focus on distinctive and innovative examples of pattern, colour and movement.

results.description: Mechanical magic lantern slides created basic moving pictures. ‘Slipping slides’ used two glass slides featuring complementary images – one stationary and one that ‘slipped’ over the other to give the illusion of movement, like crocodiles snapping their jaws. As appetite for more dynamic lantern shows increased, so did the complexity of slides. Levers were incorporated to make children appear to skip, and pulley systems used two discs to create movements like whirling windmills. Rackwork mechanisms made glass discs revolve in opposite directions to show planets orbiting the sun and were used in chromotopes to create hypnotic, kaleidoscopic effects.
description_for_label: Mechanical magic lantern slides created basic moving pictures. ‘Slipping slides’ used two glass slides featuring complementary images – one stationary and one that ‘slipped’ over the other to give the illusion of movement, like crocodiles snapping their jaws. As appetite for more dynamic lantern shows increased, so did the complexity of slides. Levers were incorporated to make children appear to skip, and pulley systems used two discs to create movements like whirling windmills. Rackwork mechanisms made glass discs revolve in opposite directions to show planets orbiting the sun and were used in chromotopes to create hypnotic, kaleidoscopic effects.

results.title: Look both ways
results.creator_credit: Sarah Watt, Bridget Ikin, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Hibiscus Films
results.brief_description: Sarah Watt’s feature film “Look both ways” is a highly unusual but most engaging narrative about death, grief and foreboding. Meryl (Justine Clarke), a talented artist who paints greeting cards for a living, she sees death and disaster everywhere she looks. These dire visions are amusingly presented in animated visions of her art work. When Meryl meets Nick there is the hope of romance; but Nick’s is saddled with his own bad news. Around these two, numerous characters swirl with an array of crisis’ to conquer.

results.title: Hairy tales
results.brief_description:
“Hairy tales” is a group-devised story made by children about a group of children who get lost in the Australian bush and who are finally rescued by a magical emu that shows them the way home.
The work was commissioned and made by a group of children who attended a filmmaking and drama workshop over three weekends at the Artplay Centre in Melbourne - a new children’s contemporary art centre established by the City of Melbourne.
The children developed the narrative using theatrical improvisation techniques taught in the workshop. The visuals were created by compositing live action and animation using a “black screen” technique providing opportunities for either drawn or filmed backgrounds that were added in post-production. The children participating in the workshops created all the content for the film. The film was directed and edited by multimedia artist Michael Buckley and produced for Artplay by creative producer, Sue McCauley.

results.title: The Happy prince
results.brief_description:
Based on an abridged version of the well-known story of “The Happy prince” by Irish writer Oscar Wilde. It tells of the efforts of a statue, the Happy Prince, to bring relief from poverty to the people in his town with the assistance of a dedicated swallow.
This digital video was made with a class of grade 6 students in a small village school in Dromohaire, County Leitrim, Ireland in late 2003-2004, and directed and edited by Michael Buckley. Sue McCauley was creative producer.
The production combined fine art practices and theatrical improvisation with digital media. The whole work was shot in the classroom at the school with backgrounds and animation added through compositing technique to create a visual richness through multi-layering of the imagery. The vision for the project was to make a work for an audience of children, primarily by children using a theatrical, ensemble, improvisational technique. Funded by the Australian Council for the Arts.
